newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia may bend on Caspian status issue -agency.
newsitem.headline: Russia may bend on Caspian status issue -agency.

text.p: Russia is ready to compromise on sticky questions over the legal status of the Caspian Sea and control over its vast oil and gas resources, Interfax news agency quoted a government official as saying on Tuesday.
It quoted the official, who was not identified, as saying Moscow was ready to consider a limited sectoral approach to the energy-rich sea.
"In our view, the compromise may be in considering the national sectors of the sea those areas 35-40 miles (20-30 km) from the shores of each Caspian state," the source said.

He said the middle of the sea would be considered the common property of the five states bordering the Caspian -- Russia, Turkmenistan, Kazakhstan, Iran and Azerbaijan -- and would be open to joint use.
The Caspian ranks eighth in the world in terms of discovered oil reserves. Reserves in Kazakhstan's continental shelf of the Caspian alone are 10 billion tonnes.
The sea has not been fully studied and may hold much more.
Russia and Iran have previously said the Caspian is a lake, and not a sea, and that its resources should be developed and shared equally.
Azerbaijan, Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan have said that it is a sea that should be entirely divided into national sectors.

The government source said Russia's approach might not please Azerbaijan, since Baku had multi-billion dollar international oil projects, some with the participation of Russian oil firm LUKoil, in what Azerbaijan calls its sector -- outside the proposed 40-mile limit.
But the source said Iran and Turkmenistan had agreed with Russia's modified sectoral proposal.
Oil industry sources have said Moscow is willing to bend on the legal status in exchange for prominent roles by LUKoil in Caspian projects.
